attributes.action: Legislate for plastics companies to make biodegradable Single-Use products.
attributes.background: Scientists are working hard to create biodegradable Benign Plastics from crude oil. This petition asks our government to legislate for companies to make single-use biodegradable plastic articles, once they are available and to prohibit making single-use plastics from the current polymers.
attributes.additional_details: Plastic producing companies are intent on making more and more polymers which will never biodegrade, remaining in our environment forever as nano plastics. Since the '70s, they have refused to take responsibility for their products once sold. Only government legislation can make such companies responsible for their products to lifespan end. Biodegradable single-use products will be safe. Government legislation will make these companies responsible for the manufacture of such safe products.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action:

Ban all single-use plastic
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/586547

attributes.action: Legislate for Plastic Producing Companies to manufacture biodegradable products
attributes.background: Encourage scientists to create Benign Plastics from oil using a grant or competition with prize. They will biodegrade at the end of their lifespan ~ Soil from Oil. Consequently, government will use its persuasive skills to encourage plastic companies to make these environmentally harmless products.
attributes.additional_details: Plastic companies are intent on producing more and more polymers which will never biodegrade and will remain in our environment for ever as nano plastics. Since the '70s, they have refused to take responsibility for their products once sold. They tell us that the consumer is responsible for litter collection. Only government legislation can improve this situation: it will make such companies responsible and at the end of their lifespan, single-use products will in any event be safe.

attributes.action: Reduce cutting our roadside verges
attributes.background: Adopt the wildlife-friendly management guidelines jointly coined by Plantlife, the Highways Authorities and other organizations on Hampshire’s roadside verges, to help wildlife and the environment, creating Carbon sinks, saving money, and achieving governmental land and environment targets.
attributes.additional_details:
Currently, many roadside verges in my home county (Hampshire) are cut 12+ times annually, wasting our taxes, and suppressing a valuable wildlife habitat. If Plantlife's management guide were adopted, these featureless verges would turn into wildflower meadows, growing far slower than the current turfs, and absorbing Carbon 3x faster than Forest. The management guide details exactly how this will be done practically and safely. Please only sign this if you live/work/study in Hampshire.

Thankyou.

attributes.action: Introduce mandatory environmental impact ratings on food products sold in the UK
attributes.background: Just as we currently have mandatory nutritional information, alcohol volume, allergy information and energy ratings on certain products, we should ask manufacturers to estimate CO2 emissions, water and plastic usage per product and to display these on their products packaging.
attributes.additional_details: An environmental impact rating would allow consumers to make informed choices when buying their food which would help individuals reduce their impact on the environment which we are beginning to see the devastating effects of globally. It would also incentivise companies to reduce their environmental impact as customers would choose to buy the products with a lower rating, thus putting sustainability at a similar priority to their profits.

attributes.action: Implement a ban on electric shock collars for dogs, and outlaw sales in the UK
attributes.background: Enact and implement a ban, promised by the then Environment Secretary, Michael Gove on these cruel, pain-inflicting training electric shock dog collars, that cause unnecessary suffering to animals. This has been introduced in Wales already. Make their sale in the UK illegal.
attributes.additional_details: These collars have already been outlawed by one of the Devolved Governments as cruel and unnecessary, but so far not in England. The Government in 2018, announced a ban on the use of hand held remote-controlled devices in England as secondary legislation under the Animal Welfare Act. However, there has been a disappointing delay in introducing this legislation. In addition, these devices are still widely available for sale, especially online in the UK, and any legislation needs to include a ban on their sale

attributes.action: Make drink producers socially responsible for all their used tin cans/bottles.
attributes.background: Move away from clear up schemes funded by the tax payer. Instead make drinks companies fund initiatives which deal responsibly with their used containers. This can be done with Reverse Vending machines (RV) already successfully deployed in many countries. The deposit/return/refund principle works.
attributes.additional_details:
It's unfair that the tax payer has to pay to clear up drink producers waste products in the form of plastic bottles and tin cans which, although recyclable, litter verges, public spaces and beaches. Producers can't ignore the issue or assume that all consumers will act responsibly. 
RV schemes will reduce a tax burden, promote good habits, conserve materials and help the environment. They can start now. We can't afford to wait until 2024 when the problem of waste clearance will be even greater.

Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

attributes.action: Block the application for exploratory oil drilling on the Isle of Wight
attributes.background: New fossil fuel extraction does not align with the Government's commitment to carbon neutrality by 2050 and the Government has now set a precedent with the Cumbria Coal Mine that new fossil fuel extraction can be blocked by act of Parliament.
attributes.additional_details: The decision on whether or not to grant the planning application to UKOG would usually be the responsibility of the Isle of Wight Council, however the Government stepped in to block to development of the Cumbria coal mine recently and thus a precedent has been set that the Government can assert itself over council decisions. Furthermore, UKOG has submitted a separate application to the Environment Agency which could take the decision out of the hands of the IOW Council.

rejection.details:
The Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government has the power to take over (‘call in’) planning applications rather than letting the local authority decide, but once a decision has been called in there is a set process that has to be followed: https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/planning-applications-called-in-decisions-and-recovered-appeals

This is what has happened in respect of planning permission for the West Cumbria Coal Mine: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/decision-to-call-in-west-cumbria-coal-mine

We could accept a petition calling for this decision to be called in, but could not accept a petition that prejudged the outcome of this process.

attributes.action: Make producers of drinks in plastic bottles or cans fund Deposit Return Systems
attributes.background: Parliament must heed Michael Gove's 2018 statement "It’s absolutely vital we act now". The shelving of the Deposit Return Scheme (DRS) until 2024 must be reassessed with the cost of Reverse Vending Machines (RVM) funded by all producers of drinks in plastic bottles and tin cans - not the tax payer.
attributes.additional_details: Looking at public spaces, road verges and beaches it is obvious that litter is a serious problem. Campaigns to Keep Britain Tidy haven't worked. Another solution is urgently needed. The DRS with RVMs will incentivise citizens to recycle, value resources and the environment -and abandon a damaging throw away, wasteful culture. In addition Highways and Local Authorities won't have to pay to clear litter. The Government is committed to a greener future. We need fine words to be acted upon.

attributes.action: Ban the use of all inhumane glue traps in the UK
attributes.background: To prevent the suffering of harmless insects, and to ensure the biodiversity of our natural environments, I am campaigning to ban all glue traps in the UK. These include pheromone traps, wardrobe glue traps (for harmless clothes moths), fly strips and ant traps.
attributes.additional_details: Glue traps are a commonly used, inhumane, and cruel method of repelling insects such as moth and flies. Tree glue traps, pheromone traps, and fly strips are just a few of these abominable methods of repelling insects, and all cause long, slow deaths for the poor creatures that succumb to them. The traps are also reducing biodiversity within our natural environments, by removing reliable food sources for creatures like owls, birds and bats.

attributes.action: Make sexual harassment and assault education in schools compulsory

We need to implement compulsory education in sexual harassment and assault so students can feel more confident in recognising and addressing situations they feel uncomfortable in.

attributes.action: The Government to revisit the Child Employment legislation
attributes.background: Child employment legislation was last reviewed in 2000 and still the primary legislation that governs this area dates back to 1920 and 1933.  Since this time there have been many changes in the employment market; the introduction of Sunday trading being just one of them.
attributes.additional_details: The NNCEE want every child to have the opportunity to work in a safe environment.  Given the impact of covid on the employment market we are very aware that young people are negatively impacted. Currently legislation does not offer flexibility nor is it fit for purpose, often making it difficult for employers to employ the young people. For example young people can only work on a Sunday for two hours, if a young person takes part in sport on a Saturday then they could not work at the weekends.

attributes.action: Create a duty to account for the impacts of government decisions on children
attributes.background: Create a binding duty that allows children, regardless of socio-economic background, to be fully and equally represented in core government decision making relating to health, environment and wellbeing, particularly where the results have potential to widen intergenerational inequality.
attributes.additional_details: In the context of Covid-19 children have had no voice in decision making. Yet this will affect their education, wellbeing, and their future prospects as economically active citizens. The proposed mitigation strategies are woefully inadequate, and children themselves are not being consulted about shaping their own futures post-Covid. Similarly with climate change, children have no right to representation in decision making that affects the sustainability of the future, which is largely theirs.

rejection.details:
Section 149 of the Equality Act 2010 sets out the Public Sector Equality Duty, which requires public authorities, including Government departments and Ministers, to have due regard to several equality considerations, including age, when exercising their functions. As this duty places expectations on the Government to consider the impact of their policies on children, among other groups at risk of socio-economic disadvantage, it is not clear what action you would like the Government to take.

You can find out more about the Public Sector Equality Duty here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/sn06591/.

As this duty requires public authorities to simply have 'due regard' to such considerations, you could start a petition calling on the Government to strengthen this requirement by enacting the Public Sector Duty and associated Equality Impact Assessments as law, if that is something you'd like to see happen.

attributes.action: Legalise and Regulate All Illegal Drugs

attributes.action: Allow university students to travel back to uni or home during lockdowns.
attributes.background: Allow all university students the choice of where they want to stay during lockdown
attributes.additional_details: Students already have enough accademic pressure on them to perform with limited teaching and hardly any support. Students are paying high costs of rent, so the least that could be done is allowing them to return to their term time accomodation during this lockdown if they want to. As they should be allowed to do there online learning in the place they feel most comfortable and their academics shouldn't have to suffer even more because they aren't in the environment they feel they can study best in.

rejection.details:
Moving back to your university home is already possible under the current guidance, if that will then become your main residence, and you don't move back and forth. You can read the renting guidance around moving home here: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-and-renting-guidance-for-landlords-tenants-and-local-authorities/coronavirus-covid-19-guidance-for-landlords-and-tenants 

You could start a petition asking for the Government to allow students to move freely between their university residence and home during lockdowns, if that's something that you'd like to happen.

attributes.action: Make a change to the exams and school/college system for students!
attributes.background: I would like them to listen to us students for once and cancel the exams. Create an environment where we can prove ourselves without exams. Make grades assessed by teachers with valid evidence submitted. Coronavirus has affected us negatively and no thought has been given to students.
attributes.additional_details:
We have had no support. We are struggling. We are COMPETING against Scotland and Wales to get into universities/colleges. Mental Health has dropped badly. There would be more support given by the students if this is sorted. We feel voiceless.
ALLOW us to have our voices heard. 
Students are struggling with exams, grades. Students would benefit more if this were sorted.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/326066

attributes.action: Legalise the use of privately owned e-scooters on public roads
attributes.background:
The UK law states that you can ride a bike, drive a car or even saddle up a horse on the road, but not ride a privately owned e-scooter.
E-scooters are better for the environment, helping ease congestion and address pollution, so I am calling on the Government to legalise their use on public roads.
attributes.additional_details:
The Government has recognised the potential with e-scooter rental trials, but privately owned e-scooters aren’t allowed on the same roads. The UK laws should catch up with many of our European neighbours.
If made legal, the benefits include: they offer an alternative to public transport – for short journeys in particular, are simple to set up and ride and better for the environment. Any new regulations should deliver safer roads and ensure that users behave responsibly and with due care.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/332067

attributes.action: Change the law on worker's rest breaks.
attributes.background: Change to, workers should have the right to one uninterrupted 20 minute rest break during the working day if they work 6 hours or more during their scheduled shift.
attributes.additional_details:
This current rule is ineffective and causes a risk to human health, and safety in the workplace. People who work in roles that are physically and mentally demanding e.g.retail and hospitality sectors. These roles require workers to endure prolonged periods of standing, in a fast-paced environment, which involves providing a service to customers, processing orders, replenishing stock, and maintaining a clean and presentable establishment.   

These activities impact the body, causing fatigue, stress, low mood, back pain, stomach pain, headaches, dizziness, etc. Which will lead to inefficiency, accidents at work, and a risk to human health.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do, the current law on resk breaks requires that workers have the right to one uninterrupted 20 minute rest break during their working day, if they work more than 6 hours a day.

https://www.gov.uk/rest-breaks-work
	
You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

You might like to sign this petition - 

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/562848

attributes.action: Change of Production Farming Regulations to protect humans and animals.
attributes.background: Change production farm regulations to reduce the risk of Pandemics and aid the protection of animal welfare. Animals in many production farms are forced to exist in an area 1m squared or less. It should become law that animals have to have at least 3m squared per animal in production environments.
attributes.additional_details:
Coronavirus originated in a wet market in Wuhan, and has ripped through mink farms in the Netherlands which have since been banned (Enserink, M. (2020). If humans have to social distance to prevent coronavirus animals needs to as well.

References 
•	Real-time tentative assessment of the epidemiological characteristics of novel coronavirus infections in Wuhan, China (Wu et al, 2020, (260 citations)). 

•	Coronavirus rips through Dutch mink farms, triggering culls (Enserink, M. (2020).)

rejection.details:
We understand you want a change to farming regulations, however it's not clear which animals you want this to apply to, nor in which specific settings. 

We also can't accept petitions containing unproven statements or inferences, such as the inference that coronavirus was first transmitted from animals to humans in a Wuhan wet market, which has not been proven. See:
- https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/28/how-did-the-coronavirus-start-where-did-it-come-from-how-did-it-spread-humans-was-it-really-bats-pangolins-wuhan-animal-market
- https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/science-and-disease/eight-key-questions-experts-tracing-origins-coronavirus-pandemic/
- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7264924/.

You may wish to sign the following petitions which call for related actions:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/330298
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/559837.

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

The Government has also created an online service to help you find out what you can do if you’re struggling because of coronavirus: https://www.gov.uk/find-coronavirus-support

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You can read impartial analysis of the Government response to coronavirus and policy developments here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/coronavirus/

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak.

Find out more: https://committees.parliament.uk/work/192/the-governments-response-to-coronavirus/

attributes.action: Ban the bang in public sold fireworks for personal garden displays.
attributes.background: Remove the loud bang from public bought fireworks. Save the noisy fireworks for organised displays in a controlled environment. Many animals & vulnerable people including service men & women with PTSD are severely affected by the weeks of loud noise made by public personal firework displays.
attributes.additional_details: I understand after many petitions asking for the ban of fireworks being sold to the public that simply isn’t going to happen. I’d like the Government or Parliament to consider a compromise by banning the sale of loud noisy fireworks to the public for personal displays. Keep the loud fireworks for controlled professional displays. This issue affects a lot of people, be it animals like my own dog who has a severe noise phobia to vulnerable children, adults & service personnel suffering from PTSD.

attributes.action: Allow dance classes during covid
attributes.background: Dance classes are an integral part to a child’s life. For many students it is an escape from their home life into an environment where they feel safe and supported. Dance classes can be made almost 100% covid safe with the use of masks, one way systems and socially distanced boxes.
attributes.additional_details: Not only are dance classes a hobby but a way of exercise which many children do not get. It is also a way of socialising which is so much more important right now due to COVID-19. There is no genuine reason as to why dance classes should be stopped as they are safer than going to the shop, going to school and walking down the road. If dance classes are stopped then this will be such a disappointment to so many children as many view dance as a second home.

rejection.details:
While dance studios are on the list of businesses that are required to close, they are allowed to open for education and training, childcare purposes and supervised activities for children: https://www.gov.uk/guidance/new-national-restrictions-from-5-november

This means that dance classes for children can continue during the current lockdown.

We have published the following petition, which you might like to sign:

Allow all dance studios to open with covid safety precautions in place: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/557275

attributes.action: Stop Lockdown restrictions
attributes.background: Stop rules regarding Covid19. We are sacrificing the mental health of our young people and our economic environment for the people who sadly wouldn't live to see the negative effects anyway.  Respect social distancing in essential areas (e.g supermarkets) for those that are shielding.
attributes.additional_details: This virus isn't going anywhere! We do not hide in this way from the flu or other colds. We have nightingale hospitals that we never used. People are losing their jobs, unable to see family, KILLING THEMSELVES. The Uk's response to this pandemic has had a worse effect on people dying from poor mental health than it has saving lives from covid19. We need to move on. We need to return to normal! Students are taking drugs out of boredom and dying. The elderly are dying alone. This is not okay.

attributes.action: Review the constraints on hospitality businesses
attributes.background: The Caterer is asking the government to reconsider its 10pm curfew on hospitality. Operators have already put in place the highest levels of safety to ensure that diners and guests can convene in a well-regulated, controlled environment, whatever the hour.
attributes.additional_details:
Asking guests to leave a premises en masse at 10pm runs counter to the aim of social distancing and only serves to increase the risk of coronavirus transmission.
We ask that the government reconsiders the 10pm curfew. The industry will continue to provide safe environments for people to eat, drink and sleep before returning to their homes in a staggered and controlled manner. This approach will stem the spread of coronavirus, aid the recovery of hospitality businesses and save jobs.

rejection.details:
We understand you want the Government to review the 10pm curfew on pubs and restaurants, but as such coronavirus restrictions are under regular review, it's not clear what more you'd like the Government to do.

You may wish to sign the following petition instead: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/551634.

attributes.action: Put David Attenborough on the £50 note (& change the colour to aquamarine).
attributes.background: The climate crisis is very evident and to honour Sir David Attenborough's life-long dedication to the environment, wildlife and marine life, he should be honoured further for this by being the face of the new £50 note.
attributes.additional_details: I would like the government to make this change because Sir David is the most influential climate & wildlife activist in the world. His work has been shown across the globe & he is dearly loved for his powerful messages by all. By having the UK put Sir David's face on the £50 note, you will not only be recognising his dedication but you will send the world an important message that individuals like Sir David must be honoured, supported and recognised. Especially in light of the climate crisis.

rejection.details:
Bank notes are the responsibility of the Bank of England, which is independent of the Government and Parliament.

You can find out how the Bank decides who will be on bank notes here:
https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/banknotes/banknote-characters

attributes.action: Allow beauticians to carry out face treatments
attributes.background: Allow beauticians to carry out facial treatments eg. face waxing, eyebrow, eyelash treatments and facials. This can be carried out in a highly clinical and sanitised environment, using all relevant PPE equipment to make this a low risk Environment protecting both parties with face mask and visor.
attributes.additional_details:
1. All relevant PPE will be worn by therapist at all times eg. mask visor apron gloves 
2. Treatment carried out standing behind the client which prevents face to face interaction
3. The client can have a face mask on whilst eyebrow and eyelash treatments are being carried out.  
4. Therapist will always have full PPE on to protect both parties during facial preventing the spread of splashes and droplets.
5. Clinical environment at the highest standard following government guidelines for cleanliness.    
This restriction needs to be lifted as these are prioty services in which a beauty salon relies upon to support the financial profit of the business.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/331169

attributes.action: Stop calories being displayed on menus in the UK.
attributes.background: We would like the UK Government to not put calories on menus, as they mentioned in ‘Tackling obesity: empowering adults and children to live healthier lives’. It encourages restrictive eating & puts in place a dangerous narrative that eating less/cutting calories is healthy for you-which it is not.
attributes.additional_details: If the Government went ahead with this plan, it could harm so many people in the UK struggling with an eating disorder, or even push other people into adopting eating disorder behaviours. It is engraining the idea into British society that your worth is in how many calories you intake, and how much you weigh- which is not true. By putting this information on restaurant menu’s it can effect people outside of restaurants and these ideals could seep into our everyday lives, creating an even more unsafe and unhealthy environment for the already 1.25 million British people with eating disorders. But these numbers can only increase if this insensitive policy is put in place.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/332940

attributes.action: One Sunday a month be encouraged not to drive, stay local & enjoy less traffic.
attributes.background: One Sunday a month we should be encouraged not to drive. I suggest the 1st Sunday of each month as will be easier to remember but doesn't really matter. A drive less campaign would be good for communities, environment and health.
attributes.additional_details:
One Sunday a month stay local & don't drive. Obviously it wouldn't be compulsory but encouraged as some people would have work or other commitments. It could be good for communities, environment and just a positive out of coronavirus.

I loved the empty roads of early lockdown. Going for a jog/walk/bike ride with minimal traffic was lovely & it was heart warming to see so many families doing the same thing. This is a positive for health & family/friends quality time.

rejection.details:
We understand that you want to see days when there is less traffic, but it's not clear exactly what you want the Government to do achieve this.

We have published the following similar petitions which you might like to sign:

Bring back Sundays being a day of rest: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310336

A yearly 2 week period where everything shuts down to let the world heal: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/306005

3 Days Off A Year To Let The World Rest: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/305055

If you want the Government to take some other action, you could start a new petition requesting this, but would need to be clear exactly what you want the Government to do.
